title: Defining the various fasting protocols
content: The overnight fast, Time restricted feeding (TRF), Alternate day fasting (ADF), Intermittent fasting (IF), 5:2 hypocaloric fast, Fasting Mimicking Diet (FMD)

title: Fasting Mimicking Diet
content: This product is ~900 to 1000 calories on the first day and  ~700 to 750 calories for days two through five. To be clear, the Fasting Mimicking Diet is a brand (like Kleenex is to tissues). But there are an infinite number of ways that one can do a reduced-calorie fast that approximates some of the metabolic benefits of fasting.

title: Types of Fasting
content: Prolonged fasting/multiple-day fasting –Clarification from Peter: You can do prolonged “fasting” via a reduced-calorie “fast” (e.g., the 5 days Fast-Mimicking Diet). In Peter’s practice, he will sometimes prescribe anywhere from three to seven days typically at about 500 to 700 calories a day (with a customized macronutrient profile). A “true” prolonged fast would be nothing but water (but also includes tea and some minerals with zero calories) for a period of time (typically three to seven days at a time).

title: Coffee and Tea During Fasting
content: There is probably some difference in the nature of the fast if you include coffee or tea, but probably not as much of an issue as “purists” make it out to be. With patients who are pretty caffeine dependent, Peter recommends NOT giving up their coffee because fasting can be hard enough without dealing with caffeine withdrawals. Eliminating coffee during a fast might improve the “gut rest” you get from a true fast. But some observers have suggested that coffee actually enhances autophagy late enough in the fast (though Peter is skeptical about that).

title: Peter's Fasting Plan
content: For the past couple years, he’s been doing a 7-day water-only fast once per quarter. For 2020, Peter plans to switch to a 3-day water-only fast once per month. Peter’s intuition is that 3 days is probably the minimum amount of time needed to hit some of the important physiologic benchmarks such as glycogen depletion which leads to inhibition of mTOR, activation of AMPK, a significant reduction of glucose and insulin that triggers autophagy and the inhibition of senescent cells.

title: Using CGM to Gain Insights into Fasting
content: Peter relies heavily on his CGM to give him insights during his fast. He looking for thinking like, “what’s the behavior of my glucose at night?”. When in a fasted state, he basically has a flat line of glucose and it’s a very low number, typically in the 60s. The only thing that can make it budge is exercise. Peter’s intuition is that there’s something relevant that’s happening when we reach a new equilibrium of glycogen and that new equilibrium takes about 3 days to get to.

title: Glucose levels during fasting
content: Peter estimates that this new baseline glucose level after 3 days is about 80% of the way to the “floor” of glucose which you might get to after about 10 days. George Cahill’s 40-day starvation experiment showed that even a month into a fast, as much as 40-50% of the energy going to the brain of those subjects was still coming from glucose, with the remainder coming from beta-hydroxybutyrate. When fasting, Peter is using the observations of i) a reduction of glucose and ii) a lack of volatility of glucose as a proxy for something physiologically interesting that’s probably happening in concert.

title: Peter's supplement protocol during fasting
content: Leading up to his 7-day water-only fasts, Peter usually eats a ketogenic diet the week prior as a way to ease the transition into using BHB for energy. Peter’s supplement protocol during fasting includes magnesium, methylated B vitamin complex, and sodium. When NOT fasting, Peter’s magnesium protocol consists of a supplement called magnesium oxide and L-threonate, which isn’t a magnesium, but it’s packaged with magnesium and it transports magnesium to the brain. When fasting, Peter’s changes out the magnesium oxide with a slow absorbing version of magnesium and he also continues to take magnesium L-threonate. He does NOT take rapamycin or metformin during a fast. On the three-day fast Peter recently did, he did NOT supplement any sodium at all and felt great (i.e., not lightheaded). On the seven-day fasts, he’s historically required two additional grams of sodium which he takes in the form of bouillon.

title: Importance of sodium during fasting
content: Bouillon is an important part of the toolkit for people because until your body really adapts to fasting and ketosis, the kidney gets pretty inefficient with sodium because it need to use sodium as an exchange to maintain potassium levels. The body really need potassium inside and outside of a cell. But the potassium outside of the cell is really critical. So the body will fight like hell for that extra milliequivalent of potassium and it will do so at the expense of sodium often and/or magnesium. So that’s why supplementing those things becomes an optimal way for your body to preserve potassium, and it’s much safer to supplement magnesium and sodium than to supplement potassium.

title: Potassium and Magnesium Supplements
content: Potassium supplements are not recommended as they don't contain enough potassium to make a difference. Sodium and magnesium are better for this purpose. Magnesium L-threonate, Doc Parsley’s Sleep Remedy, and Jarrow Formulas PS-100 are good supplements for sleep. Phosphatidylserine is another supplement that Peter takes. Trazodone is a medication that he takes on rare occasions.

title: Peter's Exercise Regimen During a Fast
content: Strength training is the best way to minimize atrophy during a fast. Peter attempts to get in at least 60 minutes of strength training per day during a fast. He includes hip-hinging, pulling, and pushing exercises in his workouts. He finds strength training more tolerable than cardio training during a fast. He takes extra rest between sets and doesn't stack exercises. He feels less pressure to nail every rep and set during fasted workouts.

title: Peter's Hunger Levels During a Typical 7-Day Fast
content: Peter does a 7-day fast from Sunday to Saturday. He feels normal on the first day but starts feeling really hungry on the second day. From day 2 to day 5 of the fast, he feels pretty hungry between 12pm-5pm.

title: Nutrition during fasting
content: By day 6… He starts to lose all sense of hunger (medical terms for this is anorexia) Case studies show people have this same complete loss of hunger generally between 7 and 14 days into a fast

title: Thyroid function during fasting
content: Your thyroid gland produces a hormone called T4 T4 is inactive so the body has to convert it into either… The active hormone which is T3; or The anti-active hormone which is called reverse T3. The amount of T3 and reverse T3 in the body is very important at regulating metabolism, body temperature, and all thyroid-related things. In an environment where food is scarce, the body absolutely wants to slow down your metabolism. The greatest tool it has for doing that is by making more reverse T3 via an up-regulation a type of deiodinase enzyme that makes it. And it will do so at the expense of making the active T3. For Peter personally… He measures thyroid function during towards the end of his fasts and he’s “blown away” at the deterioration of thyroid function. So not only has that slowed his metabolic rate down but, as a result of that, he is much more sensitive to cold. Usually a week after re-feeding, Peter’s thyroid function is completely back to normal. And after years of fasting, he’s seen no long-term signs of concern

title: Glucose, BHB, and hunger levels during fasting
content: Correlation between BHB, glucose, and cortisol levels. BHB levels and glucose levels tend to be highly inversely correlated. So when glucose comes down quickly, BHB will rise quickly. In cases were Peter’s glucose stays “stubbornly” high, BHB levels take longer to come up. For Peter, when glucose levels are stubbornly high (i.e., high 80s/low 90s) it’s generally due to cortisol (aka stress). By the end of a 7-day fast, Peter’s typically at: 5-6 millimolar for BHB, 3-3.5 millimolar for glucose. In a recent 3 day fast… During the last 36 hours, he was above three millimolar in BHB. And by the end of the 3 days he was at 3.9 millimolar (pretty typical for him). In some cases, however, his BHB don’t get as high… He’s had fasts where even 6 or 7 days in, his ketones were still in the 2-3 millimolar range

title: Impairment of Ketone Production
content: There are several factors that can impair ketone production, including cortisol, stress, and sickness. Even chewing gum sweetened with xylitol can impair ketone production.

title: Hunger and BHB Levels
content: Peter's hunger is almost completely abated around day 6 or 7 of fasting, which lines up with his ketone levels being in the 5-6 millimolar range. However, there are still times when his ketones are 3-3.5 millimolar and he doesn't feel hungry at all. It is not clear whether the 5-6 millimolar range is the moment when hunger levels dissipate altogether.

title: Circulating Concentrations of BHB and Glucose
content: In Cahill's famous starvation study, the subjects showed that glucose keeps dropping and then after a few days basically flatlines. The ketones/BHB is continually increasing for the first three weeks, peaks at ~6 millimoles after 30 days, and doesn't go up much more over the final 10 days. At 10 days, subjects were at 4-4.5 mM. Peter is surprised their ketone levels weren't higher than this after 10 days.

title: Fasting in a Ketotic State
content: People who fast who spend a lot of time in ketosis probably have a different experience than people who fast coming out of a non-ketotic fed state. Peter wishes he would have done an extended fast sometime during 2011-2014 when he was in ketosis to see what it would have been like to have done a seven-day fast in that environment when his body was really revved up and used to using ketones.

title: Sleep During Fasting
content: Peter has experienced some of the greatest nights of sleep of his entire life while fasting, but also some of the most miserable nights of sleep in his entire life while fasting. It's rarely that he's too hungry to fall asleep.

title: Peter's Sleep Regimen and Wind-Down Routine
content: Peter uses blue light blocking glasses, removes light, and lowers the air temperature of the room. He also uses the OOLER Sleep System by chiliPAD and takes supplements such as Magnesium L-threonate, Doc Parsley’s Sleep Remedy, and Jarrow Formulas PS-100. On rare occasions, he takes 25 mg of trazodone. Peter avoids Ambien and benzos because they have erosion in sleep stages.

title: Peter's Observations on Fasting for Men and Women
content: Peter has historically noticed that men tend to find fasting a little bit easier, but he is seeing more and more women go through fasting without a hitch. Women struggle more to do time-restricted feeding than men in Peter’s observation.

title: How Peter Prefers to Break a Long Fast
content: Peter likes to have some cooked vegetables combined with a small amount of protein for his first meal after a long fast. If the volume is too big, you might get the hiccups given your stomach has shrunk.

title: Peter's Experiment with Wine
content: Peter once broke his fast with a couple glasses of wine as an “experiment” and realized it hit him harder than it normally would. He was prompted to think twice about doing it again.

title: Importance of Community Support and Uncertainty with Fasting Protocols
content: Peter emphasizes the importance of community support while fasting and acknowledges the uncertainty with protocols. He believes that there is no perfect fasting protocol and that there are few tools to truly evaluate the outcomes. He has personally felt the benefits of doing a fast with others, whether in person or via social media. He recommends using the Zero app or following his Instagram for live updates on his fasting.
